abstract.t: This specification registers a kind of URI that represents a JSON Web Key (JWK) Thumbprint value. JWK Thumbprints are defined in RFC 7638. This enables JWK Thumbprints to be used, for instance, as key identifiers in contexts requiring URIs.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: A JSON Web Key (JWK) Thumbprint is a URL-safe representation of a hash value over a JSON Web Key (JWK) . This specification defines a URI prefix indicating that the portion of the URI following the prefix is a JWK Thumbprint. This enables JWK Thumbprints to be communicated in contexts requiring URIs, including in specific JSON Web Token (JWT) claims.

JWK Thumbprints URIs are being used in the specification as one kind of subject identifier in a context requiring that the identifier be a URI. In this case, the subject identifier is derived from a public key represented as a JWK. Expressing the identifier as JWK Thumbprint URI enables this kind of identifier to be differentiated from other kinds of identifiers that are also URIs, such as Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs) .

To make it explicit in a URI which hash algorithm is used, the prefix is followed by a hash algorithm identifier and a JWK Thumbprint value, each separated by a colon character to form a URI representing a JWK Thumbprint.

section.title: Hash Algorithms Identifier
section.t: Hash algorithm identifiers used in JWK Thumbprint URIs are strings registered in the IANA "Named Information Hash Algorithm Registry" .

section.title: Mandatory to Implement Hash Algorithm
section.t: To promote interoperability among implementations, the SHA-256 hash algorithm is mandatory to implement.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The security considerations of also apply when using this specification.

section.title: Multiple Public Keys per Private Key
section.t: There are cryptographic algorithms for which multiple public keys correspond to the same private key. This is described in the security considerations of as follows:

list.t: Designers using these curves should be aware that for each public key, there are several publicly computable public keys that are equivalent to it, i.e., they produce the same shared secrets. Thus using a public key as an identifier and knowledge of a shared secret as proof of ownership (without including the public keys in the key derivation) might lead to subtle vulnerabilities.

section.t: This consideration for public keys as identifiers equally applies to JWK Thumbprint URIs used as identifiers. A recommended way to ensure that the JWK Thumbprint URI corresponds to the actual public key used is to sign a message containing the correct public key with the private key. This signed message could also contain the JWK Thumbprint URI (although, by definition, it could also be computed directly from the public key).
